div.p: WHAT A BLUNDER! A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS: FIRST PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, HAYMARKET, AUGUST 14, 1800.
BY JOSEPH GEORGE HOLMAN, AUTHOR OF "ABROAD AND AT HOME," "VOTARY OF WEALTH," &C.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR W. MILLER, OLD BOND STREET. 1800.
Printed by S. GOSNELL, Little Queen Street, Holborn.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.item: Don MIGUEL DE LARA Mr. SUETT.
Captain of the Banditti Mr. SAWYER.

div.p: Nuns, Friars, Banditti, Officers of the Inquiſition, &c.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A beautiful Country with a Vineyard.—Peaſants diſcovered.

lg.l: HAPPY is the peaſant's lot,
If he know to prize it:
Comfort lodges in a cot,
Then let none deſpiſe it.
Wholeſome toil and fragrant air
Sauce our homely ruſtic fare:
And you ſee
Poor peaſantry
Are merry and full of enjoyment;
While the great,
In all their ſtate,
Are drooping for want of employment.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: Here comes Signor Lopez, head man to the Chief Inquiſitor of the province, Don Miguel de Lara. Stand back, ſtand back, and pay your humble obedience to him. (They fall back, and bow to Lopez as he enters.)

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p:
Save you, ſave you. (They bow again.) Ah, that will do; that is quite enough, good people.
It is really a tormenting thing to be a man of ſuch conſequence. I don't wonder now, that the Eaſtern monarchs ſuffer themſelves to be ſeen ſo ſeldom; for, in good truth, the homage that attends greatneſs is very troubleſome to men of indolent habits.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee your Honour look ſo well to-day.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I hope that your Honour likes theſe parts, and that you be not diſpleaſed with the folk hereabout.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Why, as to theſe parts, honeſt Diego, they are pleaſant enough. Valencia is a pretty province; but for the neighbourhood, my good fellow, that, you muſt ſuppoſe, is moſt diabolical to a man like me, uſed not only to the ſociety of Madrid, but who have lived in London and Paris. You may well conceive how wretched is my condition, if you conſider that, with all my talents and information, I am ſometimes forced, for want of better company, to come and ſit a whole hour with ſuch a bumpkin as you. It is hard, is n't it?

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I am ſorry we entertain you ſo badly; but we do our beſt, and always feel your company a vaſt honour.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: That I conſider, and therefore put up with all deficiencies. I am reaſonable, and know how to make allowances. Pray have you ſeen the two ſtrangers to-day, that have been in the neighbourhood the laſt fortnight?

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: No, Signor Lopez.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Whimſical gentlemen! They make free—ſeem to feel themſelves quite at home.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: What countrymen are they?

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p:
What countrymen? Oh, Diego, your
ignorance of men and manners!—Can any country but one, produce men mad enough to play ſuch wild tricks in his Moſt Catholic Majeſty's ſober dominions, and in full ſight of the habitation of an Inquiſitor? No, no, Diego; Engliſhmen are the only people who never conſider change of place, but are juſt the ſame harum-ſcarum madcaps in all parts of the world as they are at home: quite as ready to make an uproar in the court of the Great Mogul, as to break a lamp within the liberties of Weſtminſter.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: I did not underſtand that theſe ſtrangers were both from the ſame country.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: You did not underſtand!—My dear Diego, you ſhould only liſten, and let other people underſtand for you! Mark me—You are of the kingdom of Valencia, I of Caſtille—yet we are both Spaniards.—So one of theſe ſtrangers is of England, the other of Ireland; which though different iſlands, yet the natives of both own one country—one king—and (this in your ear, Diego) will, with one heart, defend their country and king againſt all the reſt of the world.—Here come two miſerable-looking Hidalgos—fellows, that live in dirt and poverty, from the fear of debaſing their noble deſcent, by honeſtly earning a whole coat and a good meal.

div.stage: Two Hidalgos enter with great ſtatelineſs, and the appearance of extreme poverty.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p:
Save you, ſave you. (They return no anſwer, but look at him with great contempt, and exeunt.) Theſe are precious vermin: the moſt wretched paupers, with the pride of princes.—How ſoon muſt the nation go to ruin where it is reckoned diſhonourable to be induſtrious! They have a different method
of conſidering matters in the country I was juſt talking of. Inſtead of ſeeing, as we do here, nobility made ridiculous by its entailing on future generations lazineſs and poverty, in England you will find ſome of its moſt ſtately branches raiſed from the ſtock of honeſt induſtry.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: What is coming yonder?

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Hey!—Oh! it is one of the ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: He ſeems hurt or ſick—his ſervants are wheeling him along in a chair.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: That is only one of his mad whims. He fancies himſelf in a conſumption, and went to Liſbon for the recovery of his health—there he fell in love, and is now ſearching through Spain for his miſtreſs, whoſe relations ſuddenly conveyed her from Portugal. Diſappointment has increaſed his nervous fancies, and with ſtamina to laſt a century he believes that he ſha'n't exiſt a month. This is the one from Ireland—he is called Sir Sturdy O'Tremor.

sp.speaker: Diego.
sp.p: Well, Signor Lopez, time preſſes—I muſt look to my work.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: That is right.—Farewell, honeſt Diego.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: (Without.) If you don't move me more gently, I'll break every bone in your ſkins, you vagabonds.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: There is a voice for a man in a conſumption!

div.stage: (Sir Sturdy is wheeled on in an invalid chair by two Servants.)

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p:
Gently, gently, you ſcoundrels!—Oh, the Devil fetch you, you have not a ſpark of compaſſion for your poor dying maſter. There! ſtop, ſtop; let me reſt a morſel.—Oh, it is all over with me!—Even this little bit of a motion is too great a fatigue for my worn-out frame. Come hither,
Pat.—Now, Pat,—on your conſcience tell me, don't I look like a corpſe?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: By my faith, your Honour, it muſt be a corpſe that died of a ſcarlet fever then—for your gills look as roſy as Father O'Flanagan's, when he has toſſed off the fourth bottle.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: (Starting up in a rage, and ſeizing him.) You unfeeling brute! to make a joke of your maſter's infirmities.—I'll ſhake you to atoms, you dog! (He ſhakes him, and then ſits down again.)

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: By Saint Patrick you have a pretty tight grip for a corpſe. (Walking away angrily.)

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: If that be an Iriſhman in a conſumption, Heaven keep me from the clutches of one in full health and ſtrength!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: (Seeing Lopez.) There is a ſtranger; he can have no intereſt in deceiving me.—Step this way, my good fellow; I ſuppoſe you can read in my looks, that I am not a man long for this world.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: (Aſide.) I have juſt gained a practical hint for my behaviour; ſo I know how to humour you.—Why, Sir, I am ſorry to ſay I can't flatter you.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: You are an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Not but I am perfectly aware that ſome perſons might miſtake that ruddy complexion.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Oh, a mere fluſh—a melancholy ſymptom—a hectic glow.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Yes, that is juſt what I ſuppoſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: And as for my figure, did you ever ſee ſuch a poor miſerable ſpectre?

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Oh Lord!—Oh Lord! (Aſide.)—As you ſay, Sir—your figure—but you know, Sir, on that point I am unable to ſpeak accurately, not having ſeen you otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Why, then it will ſurpriſe you to be told that I was once—a ſtout, able▪bodied man.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: I aſſure you, Sir, I am very much inclined to believe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Yes, indeed; and inſtead of this little bit of a pipe, I once had a voice like thunder.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: That I can readily imagine; for, to ſay the truth, it ſtill conveys no faint idea of that ſound.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Oh, yes—I am all faint, all feeble.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: (Without.) You lazy beggars! I will put a little motion into you; I'll make you active againſt your wills. (He enters, fighting with the two Hidalgos.)

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: (Starting up.) Two to one—fair play, you ſpalpeins! (He ruſhes on one of them, trips him up, and ſeizes his ſword at the ſame time that Daſhington diſarms the other.)

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: There is a poor feeble dying man!—If I ſtay, I ſhall certainly laugh in his face; ſo I will take myſelf hence while I am ſafe. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: (To the fallen Hidalgo.) Away, Sir!—follow your companion; and learn, that to afford aſſiſtance to females in diſtreſs is an action that, inſtead of being beneath a gentleman, a prince may be proud of. [Exit ſecond Hidalgo.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: What occaſioned this encounter?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: You ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: But firſt let me ſeat myſelf, or I ſhall ſink to the earth.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ha! ha! While a man can ſink others to the earth with ſuch eaſe, he is not in much danger of ſinking there himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Ah, my dear Daſhington! you don't know my complaints.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Very true; and, what is ſtill better, you don't know them yourſelf.—But to my ſtory. I ſaw, at a diſtance, moving along at the ſolemn
ſtately pace accordant with Spaniſh dignity, an old lumbering vehicle, that looked as if it had been a preſent from the city of London of one of their caſt-off lord-mayor's coaches. The coachman was very comfortably enjoying his ſieſta on the box. Well, on it paced for ſome time, as orderly and ſlowly as if it had been in a proceſſion; when, unluckily, a bed of clover on the road-ſide tempting the ſteeds to deviate from the beaten track, down went the carriage into an ugly kind of a hollow: I heard the ſcreams of women, and flew to their aſſiſtance. Thoſe fellows were paſſing, whoſe aid I required to raiſe the carriage. The beggarly raſcals, conſidering ſuch employment a degradation, inſolently refuſed. I however effected my purpoſe, without their help, and fortune throwing them again in my way, I was determined to pay them what I thought they deſerved.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Oh the vagabonds! I wiſh I had been with you—not that, in my feeble ſtate, I could have rendered any ſervice.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes, I think you could.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: No, no—it is all over with me.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Really!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Yes, quite.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What a pity!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: No power on earth could enable me to riſe from this chair.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, yes, yes, and I think you might even be brought to take a little walk with me, only for a mile or ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: A mile or ſo! Not there paces, if it were to gain me the wealth of both Indies.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo; I know you are not covetous; but beauty, angelic beauty, might allure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Oh, I am in a pretty ſtate for beauty to have any effect on me!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Then your caſe is hopeleſs, indeed. I am heartily ſorry for it, and I'll tell Jaquelina!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Eh! what did you ſay of Jaquelina? (Turning towards Daſhington very actively.)

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I ſaid I ſhould tell Jaquelina.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Ah! you mean if you ſhould happen to ſee that dear creature after I am dead.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: If I don't ſee her till after you are dead, your conſumption muſt be a galloping one.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Hey!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I only mean that you muſt die in a devil of a hurry, for I am to ſee Jaquelina in a few hours.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: What! ſee Jaquelina in a few hours! (Starting up.)

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul, you are on your legs again! But be compoſed—ſit down, my dear fellow; you'll do yourſelf harm—Good bye—I'll tell you all another time.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: What do you mean by another time? (Walking after him impatiently.)

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: My dear friend, you'll fatigue yourſelf to death. You know you could not walk three paces for the wealth of both Indies.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: I'd walk to both Indies to ſee Jaquelina. Where is ſhe, my dear friend?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Here—here, in this very place.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Tol lol. (Singing and dancing in great ecſtaſy.)

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Don't agitate your feeble frame.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Feeble! I am as ſtout as a lion.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
I knew I ſhould work a miracle. Now learn that Jaquelina, who was ſo ſuddenly removed from your ſight at Liſbon, was in the very
carriage which overturned this morning. I had her in my arms.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: And let me take you in my arms, my dear friend! for you have raiſed me from the grave.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But calm your ecſtaſy: ſhe is confined by bolts and bars.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: In a convent—and, what is worſe, ſhe fears that ſhe is ſoon to take the veil.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: I'll ſet fire firſt to every convent in Spain, in defiance of the Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I think you may obtain her by leſs violent means.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: How, how, my dear friend?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: That you ſhall know with all expedition. The ladies who were in the carriage with her were ſo terrified at the accident, that they were a long time before they recovered their ſenſes: ſo, while they obligingly continued fainting, we had opportunity to lay plans for her eſcape.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: But when?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: This very night.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Delightful!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And I am to be a reverend friar for the occaſion. Come along, and you ſhall know all; but, Sir Sturdy, you forget your invalid chair—You won't be ſo raſh as to walk.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Walk! Why, I could fly, if that were the only way to get a ſight of her. Allons, mon cher • mi. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.p: Surely my maſter, Don Miguel de Lara, is the laſt man in the world that I ſhould have ſuſpected of accepting a poſt in the Holy Office. He uſed to be the moſt friendly, good-humoured old fellow in all Spain: what then could induce him to become an Inquiſitor? He is mightily altered, and yet, ſomehow, the change is only ſuperficial. He frowns at every body, and hardly ſpeaks a kind word; but I have reaſon to think his heart is as humane as ever. He has ſent me to ſeek out a melancholy being who, as he underſtands, chooſes to live in this lonely place. A man can't be void of tenderneſs who courts the ſociety of the unfortunate.—This muſt be the perſon I am ſent to—I'll obſerve him a little, before I accoſt him.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Now to my painful taſk, of ſeeking commerce with that hated being man, to purchaſe means of eking out a life of wretchedneſs. Were I not forced by nature's wants to the deteſted intercourſe, I might be ſheltered in this friendly ſolitude from the ſight my eyes abhor, and my heart ſickens at—a human face. (Lopez comes forward.)—Ha! What! hunted to my very den! No beaſt of prey is chaſed by man with ſuch unwearied ardour as he purſues his fellow.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: My maſter ſent me, Sir. Good Heavens! I ſurely know that face. My Lord Alphonſo!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What, my hated name! Have I then fled to this ſecluded ſpot, ſeeking to ſhun the ſight of man; but moſt of all to hide me from their view who knew me in my days of happineſs; and muſt I ſtill meet eyes that in this wretched being trace Alphonſo?—But to your errand: your maſter ſent you; who is he?

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Chief of the Inquiſition of Valencia.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What! is that tribunal grown impolitic in cruelty, to ſeek a wretch like me to wreak its vengeance on? Thoſe who delight in human miſery ſhould ſingle out the happy, and force the groan of anguiſh from the heart that ne'er knew aught but rapture: I am ſo pre-eminent in wretchedneſs, that I can look with tranquil eye on all the horrors of the infernal court—miſnamed the Holy! Can its gloomy caverns terrify the man who loaths the ſight of day? can eternal ſilence be a puniſhment to him to whom all converſe with mankind is hateful? or can the flames which fold around the victim of its wrath, equal the fire which burns within my boſom? No, no; the flames which kindle at the ſtake, poſſeſs the mercy too to counteract the vengeance that employs them, and ſoon conſign the ſufferer to eternal peace; while here, here in this tortured heart, a fire more painful rages, and yet will not deſtroy.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: I mourn the cauſe of your diſtreſs, my Lord, whatever it be; but I was ſent to you to bear the greetings of my maſter, and expreſs his wiſh for your ſociety:—knowing you only by report, as one who ſeemed of noble bearing, and unhappy; but when he ſhall find it is the Count Alphonſo—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Peace! peace! that name no more; the ſound is hateful to me. And who are you, that know me thus ſequeſtered and diſguiſed?

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: My Lord, I was once your ſervant, and honoured by your notice: you may, perhaps, remember Lopez de M • el.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do remember you; you quitted me to travel with my brother.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: I did, my Lord, juſt before your marriage.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Silence, tormentor!

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: What daemon that delights to preſs with horrid touch upon the trem • ling nerve moſt ſenſitive to mortal agony, has ſent thee to perform his functions? Begone, thou agent of a fiend's malignity!

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: My Lord, Heaven knows I meant not to offend you.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Why then unfeelingly proclaim the event to which I owe my miſery? But, perhaps, I wrong you; you may ſtill be ignorant of my ſhame.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Your ſhame, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
Ay, marriage was my ſhame! my torment! Oh, Heaven! her lovely face ſeemed to proclaim that every virtue dwelt within her brea •• ; her beauty, while it filled the eye with admiration, enf rced homage from the heart, for it appeared the lovelineſs of goodneſs; I fancied (poor deluded wretch!) that her whole ſoul was mine; that, unworthy as I was, in me ſhe fixed her Heaven of happineſs;—ha, ha, ha! vain, weak man; and falſe, falſe, deceitful woman! A few weeks abſence loſt me this treaſure; and to a ſtranger, the acquaintance of a day, ſhe gave her heart:
but he does not live to triumph in my pangs; no, thank Heaven! vengeance ſtill was left me.

sp.speaker: Lopez.
sp.p: Your cauſe of grief, indeed, my Lord, is weighty; but ſolitude will only cheriſh what the buſineſs and the pleaſures of the world, in time, might diſſipa • e.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Talk not thus idly. The world!—ſhe was the world to me, and now ſhe is loſt, the link is ſnapped that bound me to creation: the various paſſions which poſſeſs the human heart, and point to different objects, were in mine directed all to her. Did I court honours? 'twas to laviſh them on Angelina; did wealth ſeem worth poſſeſſing? 't was that Angelina might command whatever wealth could purchaſe; did I ſeek the circles of the gay? it was that ſhe might not know a pauſe from pleaſure; for all to me was irkſome that compelled one thought or look to be withdrawn from her—Leave me; and by the regard which you profeſs, report me to your maſter, not as Alphonſo, but as a wretched, nameleſs being, to whom man can do no kindneſs but in ſhunning him, as he ſhuns all mankind. [Exeunt▪

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: DASHINGTON diſguiſed as a Friar, and Sir STURDY O'TREMOR, enter.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul! and you make a good portly reverend-looking kind of a friar.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes; and I have put on the habit of a prieſt to perform a prieſt's office, to unite two lovers: nobody can ſay I am out of character.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: You can ſcarcely conceive the palpitation of my heart at this moment.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes, I can. When you are ſo near the object of your heart's wiſhes, it is a ſymptom very eaſy to be accounted for.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: I declare now, every nerve in my whole frame is in commotion.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Natural enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Yes; and I have ſuch a fluttering here! (Pointing to his cheſt.) How my voice trembles!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: And with what difficulty I draw my breath!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Plague take your fancies! Becauſe you are agitated with joy from the hope of regaining your miſtreſs, you'd make one believe you are in the agonies of death.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: And if I were, ſhe'd bring me to life again. But, my dear friend, confeſs now, is n't it ſtrange to find an effect produced upon every part of me?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What! when the woman you love is going to leap into your arms? You are an odd fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: It clearly convinces me that all is not right.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Now it clearly convinces me that all is right. But I'll leave you now, my Herculean invalid; I'll go alone, and reconnoitre the convent. Mind that you follow me with caution.

lg.l: Oh! what a great flutter is here in my heart,
And a queer ſort of feel runs through every part,
With a heigho! dear me! well-a-day!
I ſo ſhiver, that ſurely an ague I've got,
But 't is ſometimes a cold one, and ſometimes a hot;
With a heigho! &c.
My nerves all ſo friſkily caper and prance;
They're certainly learning St. Vitus's dance:
With a heigho! &c.
With labour I force up each tremulous note,
For the words I would utter they ſtick in my throat:
With a heigho! &c.
As ſure as I live, I'm in danger of death,
For no ſign ſo ſure as a ſtoppage of breath:
With a heigho! &c.
My pulſe comes and goes too, ſo ſtrangely, good lack!
I fear it will go, and will never come back:
With a heigho! &c.
But when I my charmer ſhall ſee,
Quickly will vaniſh all ſorrow and pain;
Oh! let her bright eyes beam on me,
Then pleaſure will tingle in every vein.
And once let me call her my own,
Rapture will crown me by day and by night;
Joy then will ſo mighty be grown,
Oh! I ſhall die with delight! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Convent.—DASHINGTON and Sir STURDY enter.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Now, unleſs I ſucceed in managing the Cerberus of a gardener, and get him to open the garden gate, her eſcape is impoſſible; for the walls, you ſee, are inſurmountable.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul here is a complete fortification: ſee a light at the window yonder.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But her voice muſt give us confirmation that it proceeds from her apartment. Huſh!

sp.speaker: JAQUELINA from a Window in the Convent.

lg.l: How ſweetly glide her tranquil days,
Who, free from Paſſion's ſway,
No wiſh beyond theſe walls betrays,
Nor wafts one ſigh away:
Oh then 'tis heaven here to dwell,
For ſeraphs cheer her lonely cell.
But pity her, whom cruel pow'r
A victim here has brought,
To pine away each ling'ring hour
While abſent ev'ry thought:
Oh then 'tis horror here to dwell,
For daemons haunt her diſmal cell.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: I declare I am ready to faint at hearing that ſweet voice again.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: If there is to be any fainting, pray leave that to the lady.—Here comes the fellow that I muſt delude. Now, Sir Sturdy, to your ſtation; be vigilant, and, if I ſucceed, make good uſe of your opportunities. (They both retire.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p:
A hard kind of a ſervice this of mine, to be watch▪dog to a convent; and ſpite of all my care, I am afraid, at laſt, I ſhall loſe ſome of my lambkins. I have found many a ſheep ſtealing rogue on the look-out: hitherto I have been too ſharp for them; but what ſignifies the beſt care in the world, when the goods you have to watch are as willing to be ſtolen as the thieves are to ſteal them? Here comes a reverend father! This is
the only ſet of men I a'n't afraid of. Not becauſe I think that holineſs alway lies under a hood; but becauſe theſe father confeſſors being truſted with the ſins of their female acquaintance, why it is fair to imagine, that if they are ever diſpoſed to ſin themſelves, they need not go out of their own neighbourhood to indulge their inclinations.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Save you, father!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Benedicite! But tell me, ſon, what are you loitering about here for, at ſo late an hour? I hope you have no ill deſign?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: No: I am placed here to prevent other people's ill deſigns.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How am I to be convinced of that?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I don't know that it concerns you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: It does concern me much—My zeal—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Well, well; your zeal ſhall be ſatisfied. Theſe prieſts will pry into every body's buſineſs. (Aſide.) Here, here is the badge of my office—Here is the key of the gardens of the convent.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Are you ſure that is the key? (Offering to take it.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Am I ſure? Yes I am ſure, and I won't be called to account any more. I am doing nothing but my duty.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A ſulky, ſtubborn raſcal this. (Aſide.) I doubt very much that you are doing your duty. I have ſtrong apprehenſions that you have ſome evil intention, and therefore, to prevent danger, I'll alarm the convent, I'll— (Raiſing his voice a little.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Silence! don't let your zeal frighten my Lady Abbeſs, and the whole nunnery. I never met ſuch a troubleſome fellow in my life.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: If you don't inſtantly ſatisfy me, I'll raiſe them all—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! A'n't you aſhamed of yourſelf?—What ſhall I do? If he call up my Lady Abbeſs, I ſhall get into a ſcrape. For ſhe is a prieſteſs, and he's a prieſt; and ſo being both parſons, they'll take each other's part to a certainty. (Aſide.)—Well, well, I'll convince you—There, there you ſhall find I am no impoſtor—You ſhall ſee it is the right key.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Come then, ſhow me. (Juan opens the garden gate.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Now, are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes, yes, now it is clear you are an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Well, then, let me ſhut it again.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay; what a refreſhing odour ariſes from the flowers in this garden, and how neatly it is laid out! Ay, he is a ſkilful man, he knows his buſineſs, that has the management of theſe grounds.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Why yes—though I ſay it myſelf, I am as good a gardener as any in all this province.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ay, or the next to it, or all Spain, you may ſay, if you are the man—I muſt be better acquainted with you—I know ſomething of your art, and we'll converſe together.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Whenever you pleaſe—but I'll juſt ſhut the gate, for—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Not yet, if you love me. Delightful! exquiſite! Keep it open a little longer, my good friend; and while one ſenſe is ſo charmingly indulged, we'll try if we can't gratify another—Here, brother floriſt—here is a bottle of choice ſtuff; I never go unprovided.

div.head: FINALE.
div.stage: DASHINGTON, JUAN, Sir STURDY, JAQUELINA, Nuns and Friars.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: While the roſe's ſweet fragrance with pleaſure's exhal'd,
With wine's roſy juice let the taſte be regal'd.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Agreed; and, to prove my regard for the roſe,
I'll drink till I've painted its tints on my noſe.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Now's your time. (In a whiſper to Sir Sturdy while Juan is drinking.)

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: —My noble fellow!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: (To Juan.) Come let's drink till we are mellow.
sp.stage: (Daſhington goes up to Juan, and ſtands in ſuch a manner as to block up his view of the gate, while Sir Sturdy goes into the garden.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What a flavour! How delicious!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: (In the garden to Jaquelina.) Quick, my love, the time is precious.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Fill again.—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Oh, how alarming!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: By the maſs this wine is charming!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: Pauſe no more. (To Jaq.)—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: (To Juan.) Nay, don't give over.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Oh, I fear to truſt my fate.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: Can you doubt your faithful lover?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Now, I'll lock the garden gate.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: All is loſt then—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: (To Juan.) No, not yet, man.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: Leap, or it will be too late.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Sure the bottle you'll not quit, man;

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: But I'll lock the garden gate.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Spread your arms then to receive me.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.l: Boldly leap, and nothing fear. (She leaps.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What's that noiſe?—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: There's none, believe me.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Hark! again a noiſe I hear.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Poh! your brain with wine is heated.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Ha! a window open too.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Pſha! What folly!—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Oh, I'm cheated;
Help! here, help, I'm trick'd by you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Ceaſe your bawling (To Juan.)—Now or never.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur. and Jaq.
sp.l: Friend, I'm bound to you for ever.
Sir, I'm bound to you for ever.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Fly, your ſafety lies in diſtance. (Exeunt Sir Sturdy and Jaquelina.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Help! Oh, help here! ſome aſſiſtance! (Going into the garden, Daſhington following.)

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Silence, ſilence!—

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Murder! fire!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Will that curs'd tongue never tire?

div.stage: (Juan ſuddenly ſprings out of the garden, ſhutting the gate, and leaving Daſhington within.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: I've caught you, my jolly friar.

div.stage: (Nuns appear at the windows of the Convent, and Friars and Singing-boys enter, as from an adjoining monaſtery.)

lg.l: Whence this noiſe? Why thus alarm us?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Here am I, a pris'ner faſt.

sp.speaker: Nuns.
sp.l: Did this man intend to harm us?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Yes; and there he's ſafe at laſt.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Ladies, I no harm e'er meant you,
I'm a ſober modeſt man.

lg.l: What but miſchief here has ſent you?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Now be jogging if you can.

lg.l: A villanous deſign is clear;
No good, 't is certain, brought him here;
Moſt ſacrilegious his intent,
And he ſhall meet due puniſhment.
lg.stage: (Daſhington joins in the chorus, and ſings)
lg.l: No villanous deſign is clear,
That drunken raſcal lock'd me here;
Not ſacrilegious my intent,
And I defy your puniſhment.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Viletta.
sp.p: AH! Madam, all your thoughts go to one object.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes, Viletta, I can't help it—I ſhall love him for ever. Oh my dear handſome Engliſhman, I'll be conſtant to you in ſpite of fate!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: How will you manage that, dear Madam? You muſt marry Don Miguel's ſon, as ſoon as he comes from Lima.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, I never will.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: It is impoſſible that you ſhould prevent it. You know your father, at his death, left Don Miguel abſolute power over you as your guardian, beſides expreſsly enjoining that you ſhould marry his ſon Don Philip.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I don't care—the dear Engliſhman I met at Madrid, when I was viſiting my ſiſter, is the only man that ſhall ever have me for his wife.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: But, pardon me if I ſay you ſeem to be conſtant without reaſon.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Women, you know, will have their whims. Many are inconſtant without reaſon: my whim is at any rate the moſt harmleſs.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: But conſider he failed in his appointment when you had conſented to elope with him. He broke his word.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That was very ſhocking, to be ſure. But as I was the perſon wronged, I conceive I have a right to forgive if I pleaſe: beſides, I will never believe that he intended to deceive me. No; he is of a country too generous to abuſe its conqueſts. The vanquiſhed in war, the Briton treats with humanity; will he then fail in tenderneſs to the heart that love has made his captive?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a woman in love can always make good excuſes for her paſſion.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That is extremely fortunate, for there are very few diſpoſed to make excuſes for her.—Well, I am determined to cheriſh the dear idea of enjoying happineſs with the man of my choice.

lg.l: The hope which animates my heart,
And makes me ev'ry fear diſmiſs—
Deceitful joy can ne'er impart;
No, 't is the harbinger of bliſs.
So, when at eve, in tints of gold
The radiant clouds adorn the ſkies,
They thus prepare us to behold
The morrow's ſun in ſplendour riſe.
Yes, I'll indulge the dear belief,
That happy morrows are in ſtore,—
And truſt that voice which tells me grief
Shall never haunt my boſom more.

div.p: Here comes my old ſour▪faced guardian, and yet, to ſay truth of him, he is like the cocoa-nut, a rugged outſide with a milky kernel.
div.stage: (Don Miguel de Lara enters, attended by inferior officers of the Inquiſition: he looks ſternly at Leonora and Viletta, and ſeats himſelf at a table.—Juan and Friars enter with him.)

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Girls, what do you ſtay here for? don't you ſee I am on buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That is no reaſon we ſhould go; for your buſineſs may be our amuſement.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: I am going to try a cauſe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I like to hear a cauſe tried of all things.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: But it is about carrying a lady away by force.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh! that muſt be very intereſting: I am determined to ſtay now.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: There it is: whenever a cauſe comes on where ſomething improper is expected to be brought forward, the crier may bawl out, "Ladies, leave the court," till he croaks like a raven; but the devil a woman will budge from her place.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You are a very ſcandalous man, Guardy; and to ſhow you how unjuſt you are, we'll withdraw. Come along, Viletta. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Poor things! they are ſadly balked. Well, let me hear what this proceeding has been: where is the chief evidence?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Friar.
sp.p: Evidence, my Lord! We preſumed that every thing of which the Holy Inquiſition took cognizance was enveloped in ſecreſy.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: You did, did you? Then let me tell you, that if you come to me for juſtice, you ſhall ſee her in open daylight; for though ſhe is blind herſelf, ſhe is not aſhamed of being viewed by the whole world; and thoſe who pretend that ſhe likes darkneſs beſt, are deſirous to palm off ſome baſe counterfeit in her place: ſo let the witneſſes ſtand forward, and bring in the accuſed.

div.stage: DASHINGTON enters, guarded by Officers of the Inquiſition.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Well, and who are you?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Who am I? My friend, you ſeem to have changed places with me: that may be a very proper queſtion from the judge to the priſoner, but I never heard of its being put by the priſoner to the judge. So be ſo kind as to tell me who are you?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Does n't my habit ſpeak for me?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Not very intelligibly: it is one that commands reſpect from all, when worn by him who himſelf reſpects it; but a ſtain on that habit is more offenſive than on any other: the purer the garment, the fouler do ſpots appear on it.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Very true: but don't look ſo deviliſh ſour; you frown moſt ferociouſly.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Frown moſt ferociouſly! why, if I do, you don't ſeem much terrified at it. But I admit your cenſure; mildneſs alone becomes the ſeat of juſtice: the judge and the executioner ſhould never look alike. But what is the priſoner charged with? Who accuſes him?

sp.speaker: All the Friars.
sp.p: I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: I, I, I! Why, what a volley of I's is poured all at once! You are as eager as a ſhoal of porpoiſes to devour your wounded fellow.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Friar.
sp.p: No fellow of ours; we diſclaim him; he is a wolf in ſheep's clothing.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: And what are you? If you are one of the flock, I am ſure you are a fierce old ram, and look a great deal more miſchievous than the wolf, as you call him. But who is he, and what has he done?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I'll tell your Lordſhip all.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I'll ſave you the trouble, brother floriſt, and tell his Lordſhip myſelf.—You muſt know then, my Lord, that I have no more pretenſions to this cowl, than I have to the Pope's tiara: I put it on to deceive old Cerberus there (who, by the by, is a very honeſt maſtiff), and contrive to get the garden of the convent opened.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Oh, only to get the garden of the convent opened: a very innocent device, upon my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Was n't it? I knew you'd think ſo; you are a liberal man, my Lord, that can make allowances. Thoſe fellows ſeem to conſider the grounds of a nunnery as their own manor, and want to puniſh as poachers all gentlemen who go there in purſuit of their own game.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: A mighty hard caſe, indeed, that a gentleman can't purſue his own game for you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ay, there now, a'n't you aſhamed of yourſelves? But, my Lord, I did not go on ſport of my own, but merely to aid a friend.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: There, you ſee the gentleman did not go on his own account, but merely to aſſiſt a friend. Well, ſo you and your friend, between you, have contrived to carry away a few young ladies from the convent?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: A few! only one, my Lord, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Only one! how moderate!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And that one was a lady he doated on; a lady whoſe heart was devoted to him, as his to her, and without whom exiſtence would have been worſe than death.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul! and ſo they want to puniſh you merely for ſaving your friend's life? How ſhocking!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, you ſee things in a proper light.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and now—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe I may go?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: No, not yet; I am a little puzzled.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: About what, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Your caſe. It does not appear quite clear to me.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What! my caſe not appear quite clear?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: No; it does not appear quite clear to me, whether the Holy Office will ſentence you for this little friendly tranſaction.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Holy Office, my Lord! ſentence me!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes; whether it will ſentence you to be broke on the wheel, or to die at the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Broke on the wheel!—die at the ſtake!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes; I declare I have not a notion which.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, you are joking: ha, ha, ha! it is deviliſh droll of you. Broke on the wheel! die at the ſtake! ha, ha! how comical!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: No, not very: though I am uncertain which, it will be one or the other, I am poſitive.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Lord! you ſhould not mention ſuch horrible things, even in jeſt: I declare I feel hot and aching all over at the bare idea.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Upon my life I don't wonder at it. Leave your priſoner with me, I'll report him: officers, take charge of him. I declare I am puzzled exceedingly; I have not an idea whether it will be the wheel or a bundle of faggots. [Exit Miguel.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
My Lord, hear me! For Heaven's ſake don't leave me in this ſtate of perplexity. Oh, what a fever I am in! I ſay, my dear friend, (To one of the officers,) don't you think this is all a joke? (Officer turns away.) Oh, you ſulky dog! Pray, Sir, (To another) what is your opinion? (He puts his finger to his lips.) Oh, dear! Oh, Lord! what! muſt nobody ſpeak to me? What had I to do in this infernal country? I muſt be ſeeking adventures,
and be curſed to me! Oh, my ſweet, dear, little England, ſhall I never ſee you again? There the worſt of ſcrapes I could ever get into, would end in paſſing a jolly night in the watch-houſe; a jobation from the Juſtice next morning; and the loſs of a few guineas for ſmaſhed panes of glaſs, and watchmen's broken heads. Oh, Lord! Oh, Lord! that I ſhould ever be in ſuch a dreadful plight!

lg.l: Oh! what a moſt horrid▪ſenſation
I feel at this terrible minute!
A curſe on this flame-loving nation,
That I ſhould be ever caught in it.
The bent of the mind
From its pleaſures we find;
And what is a Spaniard's delight?
Why his great holiday,
Is an auto da ſé,
And its bonfires the joy of his ſight.
Ah! ſhortly there 'll be
A blaze made of me,
At ſome joyful event's celebration:
On a feſtival night
They 'll ſet me alight
To make part of a grand 'lumination.
The national taſte
In horror is plac'd,
Their Eſcurial's a ſymbol of malice:
They, plainly to prove
For torture their love,
In a gridiron's ſhape built a palace.
For a fault e'er ſo ſmall,
Or for no fault at all,
Here a man dies the death of a ſinner:
As goſpel 't is true,
He 'll be burn'd for a Jew
Who cannot eat pork for his dinner.
What an idiot was I
Dear England to fly,
Where good humour ſo juſtly is boaſted;
Oh, curſe on ſuch folk
As can't take a joke:
Here muſt I for a frolic be roaſted. [Exit guarded.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Does the woman we brought home yeſterday ſeem any better reconciled to her new habitation and acquaintance?

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Not a bit. Damn it! ſome people can never be contented.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: She muſt be curſed hard to pleaſe; for if ſhe were to ſearch all Spain, ſhe would not find a more accompliſhed ſet of adventuring gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Very true; but you know an ill name goes a great way with prejudiced people; and let a man be as valiant as Caeſar, and as fine a gentleman too, only call him robber inſtead of conqueror, and all his good qualities go for nothing.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: What you ſay has too much truth in it. But there muſt be ſomething particular about this woman, or ſhe would ſurely know when ſhe was well off. What can you find out from her?

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: That her name is Angelina, the wife of Count Alphonſo d'Eſparza; and when we plundered her and brought her to this cavern, ſhe was in purſuit of her huſband.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: There you ſee, Vaſquez, the perverſeneſs of the ſex. Now ten to one if the huſband had not run away from her, but ſhe would have run away from him: this accounts for her diſlike to us. If her huſband were of the party, ſhe would ſoon ſhow us the preference.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: But to buſineſs: it is fixed that we ſhall plunder the houſe of Don Miguel the Inquiſitor this very night.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: I am ready: the more deſperate the buſineſs, the better I like it.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Then this is an undertaking not to your mind; for it will require more caution than enterpriſe, as we are certain of eaſy admittance.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: We have diſcovered that this cavern communicates by a private entrance with a dungeon of Don Miguel the Inquiſitor's houſe; ſo in the dead of night we can make good our entrance without noiſe. Look, here comes the woman; ſhe is deviliſh handſome: ſtand aſide.

lg.l: Pent within this cavern drear,
Captive of a ruffian crew;
Startled at each ſound I hear,
Shudd'ring at each face I view;
In dread I paſs the gloomy day,
And weep the ſleepleſs night away.
Ere I mourn'd a fate ſo dire,
Sorrow was an inmate here;
Still her beams of heavenly fire,
Hope diſplay'd my breaſt to cheer.
The gladd'ning ray ſhe now denies,
For dimm'd is hope when freedom dies.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Here come ſome of our party. See the Captain,—ha! and another woman.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Damn it, what a high poliſh our manners will get! for I am told nothing improves the behaviour ſo much as female ſociety.

div.stage: JAQUELINA, the Captain, and more Robbers, enter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ha! A companion in misfortune!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: What dreadful place is this?—Oh reſtore me to liberty, and you ſhall be rewarded to your utmoſt wiſhes. Oh Madam, entreat for me!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I entreat for you and for myſelf, for I, like you, am a wretched captive.

div.head: TRIO AND CHORUS.—
div.stage: JAQUELINA, ANGELINA, and Captain of Robbers.

sp.speaker: Jaq. and Ang.
sp.l: Compaſſion to our woes impart,
Nor vainly let us ſue;
The breaſt that owns a valiant heart,
Is ſtill to pity true.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Try no more this uſeleſs wailing,
Think not that my ears aſſailing
You my rugged heart can move.

sp.speaker: Jaq. and Ang.
sp.l: Kindly grant us freedom's bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Vain is all this earneſt preſſing.

sp.speaker: Jaq. and Ang.
sp.l: Joys that flow from mercy prove.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: Ne'er ſuch weakneſs will I prove.
Learn that I drew my infant breath
Within the robber's cave;
And when too young to deal out death,
I dug the dead man's grave.
Then think you that a woman's tear
Can make this boſom feel?
I'm dead to pity as to fear,
My heart is cas'd with ſteel.

lg.l: Then think you that a woman's tear
Can make our boſoms feel?
We're dead to pity as to fear,
Our hearts are cas'd with ſteel.

sp.speaker: Jaq. and Ang.
sp.l: Be ſoften'd by a woman's tear,
And for our ſorrows feel;
To pity wake, though dead to fear,
Nor caſe your hearts with ſteel.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Miguel's Houſe.—LEONORA and Don MIGUEL enter.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My dear Guardian, what is this ſhocking thing I hear—

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: How ſhould I know what ſhocking thing you hear?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Of the young gentleman in the friar's habit?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Well, and what of him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That he is in danger of being puniſhed.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: And ought he not to be puniſhed?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, I think not.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Indeed! What! not for being concerned in carrying a lady from a convent?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No!—if the lady was willing to go from the convent.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Really?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes, really. Force certainly ought to be puniſhed; and therefore, puniſh thoſe, dear Guardy, who placed her there. For ſurely it is a greater crime to put a lady into a convent againſt her conſent, than to take her away with her conſent.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p:
The young gentleman has a mighty warm
advocate in you▪ and I really believe, that if he were to be tried by a jury of ſpinſters, they would not heſitate long in pronouncing him—Not guilty.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And do you now, my dear croſs-looking good-natured Guardy—do you pronounce him—Not guilty. Conſider, ſhe is no nun, that is carried off. She had not taken the vows; therefore, there is no harm at all in what he has done—Now is there?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: A thought has ſtruck me—you ſhall go to him.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Shall I? Oh, thank you, dear Guardy.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes; and you ſhall tell him from me, that I ſo much compaſſionate his ſituation—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That is ſo kind, now.—Well, well.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: That I will exert all my intereſt—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Ay, do now; there is a dear Guardy.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes—that I will exert all my intereſt—to have him—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What?—What?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Only impriſoned ſor life.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh, frightful!—Impriſoned for life!—I declare you are quite horrible!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes,—impriſoned for life:—ſo far you may ſay from me!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Pſha!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Yes, but you may ſay from yourſelf—from yourſelf—mind, not from me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well!—What?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: That if he don't like my propoſal, and wiſh at the ſame time to ſave me a great deal of trouble—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: That he had better—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Better do what?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Scamper away as faſt as he can.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Oh, you dear good creature!—I'll go to him directly.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: No, no, on ſecond thoughts, I'll order him to be brought here, and I'll take meaſures ſo, that nobody ſhall be in the way to prevent his eſcape. [Exit Miguel.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: How happy I am that this poor young man will be ſo ſoon freed from his fears!—How delightful it is to lift off the load of miſery from the boſom ſinking under its preſſure! Ah! where is he who alone can baniſh affliction from my boſom?

lg.l: Again my abſent love to meet,
Severeſt toil with joy I'd greet;
At noon through Afric's ſands I'd go,
At midnight pace the realms of ſnow.
When found, ſuch rapture would be mine
As words can ne'er reveal;
For ah! the bliſs of love divine
The heart can only feel.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What the devil is to be done to me now? I am to endure a little thumb-ſcrewing, mayhap; or they may be going to amuſe themſelves with drawing a row of my teeth; or, leſt confinement ſhould injure my growth, they intend to ſtretch me out half a foot or ſo. Some pleaſant little experiment is to be tried, no doubt. What!—A woman! My dear, dear Madam, if you have a grain of compaſſion—Hey!—It is ſhe! The lovely creature I met at Madrid.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: O Heaven! Is it you? you that I am to ſave?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And can you, indeed, ſave me?—Oh you dear angelic creature! (Going to embrace her.) But I muſt not be too free with my raptures. I remember I had a gentle hint once given me that you were another man's property.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What do you mean?—I another's property? Inſulting man! do you meanly attempt to defend your own inconſtancy by falſely accuſing me?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Not I. I don't accuſe you of inconſtancy. I own myſelf greatly honoured by your very flattering partiality; but—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Why, as you know another perſon has a certain claim to you—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That, I conceive, was my conſideration, not yours; and when I offered you my heart, were you mean enough to yield your claims to the frivolous pretenſions of another. Fie, fie! I thought more nobly of you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: There it is now—when a woman has a mind to follow her inclinations, her huſband's claims are mere frivolous pretenſions. (Aſide.)

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, no; inconſtancy, not fear, induced you to break your appointment. That penetrable boſom was pierced by ſome new object.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: My dear Madam, you have hit it exactly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: And do you confeſs it?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Upon my ſoul there is no denying it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: This audacity is inſufferable.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Patience for one moment, my angel!—Heaven knows, I mean this not in the language of figure, but as mere diſmal matter of fact. My boſom was pierced by an object new to me; but not ſuch an object as your fancy pictures, with a
ſmooth ſmiling face; but by one with a pair of frowning brows, and fierce muſtachios.—The weapon that wounded me, was not a ſparkling eye, but a damned long ſharp toledo; and inſtead of being prevented from obſerving my appointment, by the act of breathing out my ſoul from my lips, it was hurrying very faſt out of my body, from a hole that a friend of yours did me the kindneſs to drill through me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My torment is then returned, and I am doomed to miſery.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Torment!—Ah, that means huſband all the world over.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But how was he acquainted with our attachment?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To my ſhame, I own, by my indiſcretion. You remember at our laſt meeting, you kindly fixed the day on which you would explain to me all the particulars of your ſituation, and fly with me from Spain.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes, yes—how I repent my weakneſs!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Buſineſs in the mean time called me ſome miles from Madrid.—I however poſted with a lover's ſpeed to obſerve the appointment—a violent ſtorm, which though I was diſpoſed to brave, not all my efforts could perſuade my ſteed to encounter, obliged me to ſeek ſhelter at an inn. There I found a certain gentleman, likewiſe weather-bound. Obſerving my anxiety to proceed on my journey, he inquired the cauſe.—I fooliſhly revealed it—on which he furiouſly called me villain, beſtowed ſome hearty curſes on you, Ma'am,—ſo to tilting we went—and as it happened, he left me, to all appearance, not likely to be any man's rival in future.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: 'Twas certainly Don Philip. But how could you deſcribe me? for I never had revealed my name to you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But that I had unluckily diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: What became of your adverſary?—Was he hurt?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yes:—I pinked him a little. But ſuppoſing me killed, I learned that he was immediately removed in a litter, and what became of him I know not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He is certainly dead.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What, then, you have neither ſeen nor heard of him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No; and you are now in the houſe of his father.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: The devil I am! What, then, the old gentleman, who was a little puzzled whether I ſhould be broke on the wheel, or die at the ſtake, is his father?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, then, I dare ſwear he'll ſoon make up his mind.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: He had kindly conſented to releaſe you. Fly, fly, while you have the power; for ſhould Don Miguel learn that you are the murderer of his ſon— (During this ſpeech Don Miguel enters behind)

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: What do I hear? The murderer of my ſon! Oh the villain! What a mercy it is that I have you ſtill in my power!—Here, Sancho—Perez— (Two Officers enter.) take this ruffian—put him into a dungeon.—Oh, my poor boy Philip!—Well, though I can't reſtore you to life, I'll be revenged on your murderer.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: From my ſight this moment bear him.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Now I fear I'm quite undone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You intended, Sir, to ſpare him.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: What! the man who kill'd my ſon!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Sir, my nature is not bloody.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: Take away that tiger whelp.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: He pok'd me quite through the body.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What he did he could not help.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Bleſs me, Sir! you're vaſtly cruel,

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: To revenge a murder'd ſon!

sp.speaker: Daſh. and Leo.
sp.l: He fell fairly in a duel,

Which he would not let
me
him
ſhun.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: How can you plead for the villain?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, I plead for juſtice ſake.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: If I die your ſon for killing,
Let it not be at the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: You ſhall die my ſon for killing,
And it ſhall be at the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hear me plead for juſtice ſake.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.l: Wedded to my country's faſhion,
I would rather far be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: Zounds! you but increaſe my paſſion;
I'll no longer be harangu'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, let mercy temper paſſion,
And with patience be harangu'd.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.p:
Here is a bleſſed night for a man in a conſumption! But I ſhould not mind all this ſoaking and pelting, if I only knew what is become of
my dear little girl. I thought to find her ſo ſnug and ſo cozey at the village where I ordered my man Pat to conduct her. Sure honeſt Pat has n't turned out a big rogue, and carried her back to the convent! Blood and fury! Why did I leave her in any body's care, without ſtaying myſelf to ſee that they did as I ordered them? I am in a pretty kind of a hobble. I left my miſtreſs, to look after my friend, and now I have loſt both.— (Coughs.) Oh, this devil of a night! (Coughs again.) There is your true genuine hollow churchyard cough. Yes, yes, I may truſt to this for doing my buſineſs expeditiouſly; otherwiſe, what fine rheumatics and lumbagos this precious drenching would lay in ſtore for the amuſement of my old age! (A ſhriek at a diſtance.) Ha! the ſcream of a woman! Perhaps it may be Jaquelina—if not, 't is certainly a woman—and in danger—and when that is the caſe, one is n't to wait to know whether ſhe is one's own woman, or whoſe woman ſhe is—for every man is every woman's natural protector. [Ruſhes off.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Changes to that part of the Foreſt where Alphonſo's Cottage ſtanas.—Storm continues.—ANGELINA runs on, and then ſupports herſelf againſt a Tree.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
I have at length eſcaped them. Overtaken by the ruffians in my flight from their horrid dwelling, I muſt again have been forced thither, but for the generous man who flew to ſuccour me. Bleſſings, bleſſings on him! I am ſadly faint. My ſtrength is gone—quite gone—Should they vanquiſh my deliverer, and again purſue me, I
am loſt. (Attempts to proceed, but finds herſelf unable.) Oh feeble, feeble limbs! will you betray me?—I feel a faintneſs at my heart. Oh, exhauſted quite—Heaven have mercy on me!— (Sinks down, fainting.)

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! ſuch a night as this has charms for me—Now are the elements in uniſon with my perturbed boſom—Methinks I could endure exiſtence without repining much, would Nature always look thus terribly. I love her in this garb of horror—When ſhe is thus arrayed in night's black mantle, adorned with vivid flames—then, then I hail her, for ſhe ſeems as ſhe had not forgot there are ſuch wretches as myſelf, to whom her ſmiling looks and robes of gaiety are hateful, and appear as much the guiſe of mockery, as would the gewgaw dreſs of maſking revelry at the laſt ſolemn rite paid to the dead.—This is a night to ſcare the guilty. The elements are now my miniſters of vengeance—they give to conſcience tenfold terror. The thunder echoes her reproaches, and the fierce lightning vouches for Heaven's wrath. Now that falſe heart that wronged Alphonſo trembles! 'T is juſt, 't is juſt, oh cruel Angelina; for what a wretched being haſt thou made him!—Haſt thou not changed his very nature? He who once felt tenderneſs for all, has now no feeling left for any human being, but abhorrence— (Angelina groans.) What is that? (She groans again.) The cry of miſery.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! ſome help, or life forſakes me!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
Ha! a woman's voice! She called for help—Well—death beſt adminiſters it. (Going.)
That's harſh—that's harſh—ſhe never wronged me—ſhe may be ſome poor deſerted being, like myſelf—victim of perfidy. The wretched, however they may ſhun the offices of kindneſs to the proud and happy, who diſclaim them, ſhould ſtill relieve the wretched.—Poor creature, though perhaps I do thee wrong to lengthen life, the little aid that I can give, I won't withhold. Come, let me hide thee from the drenching ſtorm beneath this roof, which I ne'er thought would lodge a human being but myſelf—but miſery ſhould be a paſſport every where.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: A Dungeon, with a Lamp burning.
DASHINGTON, in the Samarra Habit, diſcovered with JUAN.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: WELL, here you are, ſafely lodged, and properly habited! You have helped me into a new poſt, for I am appointed one of Don Miguel's officers; and to ſhow that I am worthy of my truſt, I ſhall look after you pretty ſharply. Now, my friend, you are to obſerve, that ſilence is particularly inſiſted on by the holy and merciful • nquiſition, whoſe priſoner you have the happineſs to be. So—mum—no noiſe, or by virtue of my office, I muſt be under the neceſſity of exerciſing wholeſome chaſtiſement. Take my hint—make yourſelf comfortable, and don't be clamorous. Having now ſaid all that is neceſſary, remember our converſation, in future, muſt be in dumb ſhow. [Exit Juan.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
O Lord, O Lord! I have brought my adventures to a pretty cataſtrophe. Oh, what a curſed blockhead have I been, to play ſuch pranks in a country where there is this odious, horrible Inquiſition!—A pretty figure I make, with their curſed jacket of flames and devils!—
But I wiſh that were the worſt part of the buſineſs. If they would let me out alive, and with whole bones, I would be contented to do penance in this pretty veſtment, up St. James's Street and Bond Street, for the reſt of my life. Nay, that would be no puniſhment, for I dare ſwear, as ſoon as this queer coat was ſeen there, it would be thought ugly enough to come into faſhion. All my fine women, too, in compliment to me, would dreſs à l' Inquiſition; and for a whole ſeaſon, at leaſt, nothing would be voted ſtyliſh that was not of the devil and bonfire pattern.—But here am I lodged in this black hole, and my only promenade will be to a bundle of faggots, where I and my jacket will be turned into cinders and tinder. Oh, curſe it! how horrible! Never did I expect to make ſuch a flaming exit. (A noiſe without.)—Hey! what is that noiſe? (Noiſe again.)—Ah! they are coming for me. They don't keep me long in ſuſpenſe. Oh, curſe it! what a pity that ſuch a fine flouriſhing ſhoot, in full vigour, ſhould be condemned for fire-wood! (The private entrance through the wall is opened.)—Ah, they are here; it is all over with me!

div.stage: Enter Robbers, with caution, not ſeeing DASHINGTON.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! tread ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, you need not ſtand upon ceremony.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: We ſhall ſoon finiſh the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I dare ſay you will—What a curſed hideous crew!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: What is that? (Seeing Daſhington.)

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: It is a ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Not yet, but I ſoon ſhall be. What an effect my miſery muſt have on my viſage, when
I even frighten the fellows who come to look for me!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: It muſt be a ghoſt.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Ghoſt, you blockhead! It is one of the Inquiſitor's priſoners.—Are you not, fellow?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: I am, I am—but I would much rather be a ghoſt of the two, if I could be made one without any preparatory ceremony.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: If you are a priſoner, we will ſet you free.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Set me free? What! Set me free?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Yes, on one condition.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Any, any condition, my dear friends; for there is nothing I would not ſooner do than be roaſted.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Follow us, then, to plunder the Inquiſitor's houſe.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: To plunder the Inquiſitor's houſe!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Yes, but that will not content you; you want to be revenged—Well, you ſhall; we mean to make him and all his family quiet, that they may not tell of this midnight viſit.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Oh, you do!

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Yes, I knew you would be pleaſed to find Don Miguel's throat was to be cut.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, upon my ſoul I am not.

sp.speaker: 2d Rob.
sp.p: Not by any body but yourſelf, you mean. Well, well, we'll indulge you—There— (Throws him a dagger.) You ſhall do that buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: (Takes the dagger.) No, I'll be damned if I do. Look ye, gentlemen, I thought you were come to perform rather an ugly kind of office. That you are not, believe me I am truly grateful; but I think that taking the life of another would be an awkward way of ſhowing my joy for the preſervation of my own.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Stay where you are, then, and we'll ſoon diſpatch—

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt—I will neither cut throats myſelf, nor ſuffer them to be cut by others, without doing all I can to rouſe their owners to look after them. I'll try, therefore, if my windpipe can preſerve other people's.—Holloa!—Murder!—Robbers!—Murder!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Silence, villain!—The houſe will be alarmed!—Seize him! gag him! and bear him with us. We will make you rue this outcry.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: (Without.) What the devil do you make all that bawling about? Did not I tell you to be ſilent?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Rob.
sp.p: Make haſte!—Cloſe the entrance, or we are diſcovered and ruined. (As the Robbers are carrying Daſhington through the private avenue Juan enters.)

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Oh, Lord! oh, Lord! What is all this? See, a parcel of devils are flying away with him through the wall—He's a ſorcerer, as ſure as fate—That I ſhould ever ſee ſuch a ſight!—Help, help! Murder! Devils! Help!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: What are you making this uproar about? Speak!—What is the fellow ſo frightened at?—Where is your priſoner?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Gone, gone, gone.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Gone! Oh, you villain!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: It is no fault of mine—it is no fault of mine.—How can I keep a priſoner if a party of devils chooſe to fly away with him?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: What does the raſcal mean?—Confeſs, you dog, confeſs!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I'll confeſs all I know—but I am ſo frightened.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Speak, you villain!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I will, I will, I will. You muſt know, then, my Lord, that I locked the priſoner in this dungeon, as ſure as I ſtand here a living man, and cautioned him, in a friendly way, not to utter a ſyllable, or I ſhould be obliged to come and thump him. Well, my Lord, all was quiet for ſome time, till at laſt I heard a noiſe, which, at firſt, I was fooliſh enough to believe was made by the priſoner—but if I had thought a moment▪ I might have known it was nothing like a human voice, for it was juſt as if all the wild beaſts in the foreſt had been roaring in a thunder-ſtorm.—Well, my Lord, in comes I—and—oh! I ſhall never forget it the longeſt day I have to live—what did I ſee but the whole dungeon in a flame of fire, and a troop of devils flying away with the priſoner through the wall.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: You raſcal! you have made a fine ſtory to account for your villany. This won't do with me—ſo I ſhall leave you in his place, and we'll ſee if any of his devil friends will be ſo obliging as to fly away with you.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Show ſome pity to me, pray, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: Here you certainly ſhall ſtay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Oh, my Lord! 'twill be my death.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: Shall a dolt like you deceive me?

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: What I've ſaid is true, believe me.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: You as well may ſpare your breath.
I'll ſhow you, you knave, how I puniſh deceit:
Let him here be lock'd up, and have nothing to eat.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: To be kept without food will not puniſh me much;
I'm in too great a fright, Sir, one morſel to touch.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: As the pris'ner you ſay,
Was by fiends borne away;
You ſhall wait till they bring him again.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: But ſuppoſe it their whim
To take me to him,
Think what will become of me then.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.l: (To Off.) Let no one come here
As my vengeance you fear,
Till I myſelf open the door.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.l: Then poor I ſhall be found
Dead with fright on the ground,
If I'm not whiſk'd away long before.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Officers.
sp.l: No one ſhall come here
(We to duty adhere),
Till you yourſelf open the door.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Inſide of Alphonſo's Cottage.—ANGELINA aſleep on a Couch.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: 'Tis now broad day, and time that I ſhould offer to my poor ſtorm-vanquiſhed gueſt ſuch viands as my humble cot affords. She ſtill is ſleeping—Well, I will not diſturb her ſlumbers, for reſt gives beſt refreſhment.—Soft—ſhe moves.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: (Still ſleeping.) Alphonſo! my Alphonſo!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
My name! 'Tis ſtrange! Pſha! Self, ſelf will ſtill be foremoſt. Are there not more Alphonſos than the wretch whom his falſe wife has driven to miſery? She calls, perhaps, on one,
whoſe dear remembrance her faithful boſom cheriſhes, while he may have abandoned her, and heape ſuch anguiſh on that heart, as falſehood hath lodged here. Let me behold the face of her whoſe ſorrows I conceive akin to mine. Immortal powers! Has madneſs maſtered my poor tortured brain, and do my eyes act as the vaſſals of diſtempered fancy? or has juſt Heaven, thus by a miracle, directed the guilty Angelina to her wronged huſband, to enforce the vengeance due to her crime? (Pauſes.) All ſurrounding objects are reflected to my ſenſe with truth's diſtinctneſs.—Can I err only here? No, no! 'Tis ſhe, and ſent, that death, death by his hand ſhe hath wronged, may expiate her perfidy. Why does my heart ſhrink from an act of juſtice? How miſery diſarms reſentment! Yes, yes; 'tis that unnerves me. Did I behold her in the hall of ſplendour, decked in the robes of gaiety, her eyes ſparkling with bliſs, then ſhould I ruſh eager for vengeance, and exult to lay triumphant guilt in ruin. But here I view a wretched creature whom Heaven's hand hath humbled. Is that pale cheek, where ſufferance is marked with care's ſure traces—is that a ſtimulant to vengeance? Poor ill-fated girl! Thy heart has played thee treacherouſly—it wanted firmneſs to prevent thy falſehood, and yet has not been ſlack to upbraid thee with it. I did not think to have wept for thee, frail Angelina; but thus, thus fallen, even I can pity thee. (Alphonſo turns away weeping.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
(Wakes and looks round.) Soft—Where am I? My mind is confuſed—Ay, ay, now I remember ſinking under fatigue and terror in the laſt night's ſtorm; and ſure ſome friendly hand conveyed me to this ſhelter. Ah! (Seeing Alphonſo.)
I truſt I now behold my kind protector. (Throws herſelf at his feet.)

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: True, you do indeed behold him who was once your kind protector. (Turning towards her.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh, Heaven! My Alphonſo! Then am I bleſt: here will I cling for ever. (Throws herſelf into his arms; he averts his head, and looſens himſelf from her embrace.) Why do you avoid me? why throw me from you?

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Falſe, falſe, perfidious, ſhameleſs woman!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh, this I feared! My honour has been wounded by the tongue of ſome baſe wretch.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: It has—by his to whom you gave your honour.—Now, now, falſe woman, what will avail your proteſtations? Now call to Heaven to witneſs for your faith, and damn yourſelf more deeply. 'Twas not the breath of doubtful rumour told an abſent huſband that his wife was faithleſs. No—the curſed tongue that lured you to diſhonour, that tongue pronounced the infernal truth, and—became dumb for ever.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Then juſtly did a villain periſh; for if ever the tongue of mortal could truly charge me with an act, however trivial, or one word or look, that ſpoke my heart wandering from thee, may Heaven withhold from me its mercy, and let the fierceſt pangs that dying ſinners tremble at, be my eternal lot! Oh, my Alphonſo, ſpurn not, as faithleſs, her whoſe deareſt, only joy, has been thy love; her who, if all the world combined to load thee with its hate, would ſtill cling to thee with increaſing fondneſs; and who, if miſeries preſſed on thy brain too great for reaſon to ſupport, would tend thee in the cell of madneſs, and even there derive more ecſtaſy from one kind look given in the tranſient intervals of ſenſe, than all the unruffled
pleaſures that the world without thee can afford!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Oh, how finely does woman's glowing fancy picture the charms of conſtancy, while her warm boſom mocks the ideal bliſs, and burns for each new lover! Angelin—Woman—Woman, I ſay—No arts, no well-imagined fiction of pure faith—no tears—no, not the genuine drops of true repentance, which atone ſome crimes, can a crime undo. Truth has proclaimed thy perfidy—my ears, which heard the horrid tale, are ſhut to denial and to palliation.—My heart is chilled—heart ſaid I? No, no, that I long ſince gave you—you deſpiſed the worthleſs gift, and threw it from you; but it has ne'er returned to warm this boſom—No, all here is cold as death.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Cruel Alphonſo! Turn your remembrance to our paſt affection. Think on the days—the years we have lived together—Could love like mine be feigned? Oh, were our dear children here, they would ſurely waken ſome tenderneſs for their poor mother!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Angelina! (Endeavouring to ſuppreſs his tears.) Shame on this weakneſs! but think not, though my eyes betray a ſympathy with miſery, that my ſoul can ſympathize with guilt, or that the ſacred compact of affection plighted to purity, ſhall remain firm to falſehood. To chain the living to the dead, is not to nature more repugnant, than to link honour with pollution.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Alphonſo—

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: No more—Farewell, thou once adored, farewell for ever! (He breaks from her, and exit.)

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Yet hear me—Stay, Alphonſo—Till death I'll follow thee—till death proteſt my truth.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Robbers' Cavern.—JAQUELINA and DASHINGTON diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How oddly people are thrown at one another in this ſtrange world!—To meet you here—

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Is ſurpriſing; and providential too, I hope.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Good ſociety, to be ſure, makes the diſmalleſt place cheerful; but I can't help wiſhing that you and I were chatting together ſomewhere above ground.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Are there no means of eſcape from this horrid place?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: None that immediately occur to me.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: The Robbers are now on ſome ſcheme of plunder—We are alone in the cavern—try the entrance, it may chance they have neglected to faſten the trap.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: There is no hope of that; for you muſt know my ears were on very active duty as they went out, and I heard the door fall with a diſmal bang, and the ruſty wards of the lock move with an infernal grating. No, here are we pretty birds faſt in our cage—we have no opportunity at preſent of uſing our wings.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: How wretched is our ſituation!

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Moſt diabolical.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Perhaps they have not ſecured the private avenue, through which you were conveyed.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Probably not; but I would rather be excuſed from making my eſcape that way. Of two evils, I ſhould think it wiſer to ſtay in my own houſe a • d be robbed, than avoid a burglary by eſcaping into my neighbour's while it was in flames.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Be confident of Don Miguel's mercy. I know his character for humanity—be aſſured you have much leſs to dread from him than from the ſavages who inhabit here—beſides, the ſervice you rendered in defeating the intentions of the villains, muſt plead for you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Eh! I have a great mind to try.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Don't heſitate—conſider 'tis our only means of eſcape.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: True—well,—do you follow me—but I heartily wiſh I may be lucky enough to find any other hole to creep out at. [Exit.

lg.l: Oh, ſhould I eſcape from this place full of woe,
And joyful preſages ariſe in my breaſt,
Such tranſport I then ſhall be fated to know,
That ſure I ſhall be of all mortals moſt bleſt.
Can pleaſure be pictur'd, their joys to exceed,
Who freedom's dear bleſſing ſecurely retain?
Yes, ſweeter their bliſs, who from bondage are freed,
And liberty, loſt to them, welcome again. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.p:
I believe I am ſafe yet.—Oh that I may continue ſo!—May be the devils don't think me worth fetching. I pray heartily they may hold in that mind. Never ſhall I forget the frightful ſight. I have not courage yet to look to the ſide of the dungeon where they vaniſhed.—If I were to ſtay here for a year, I ſhould not take a wink of ſleep, for fear of finding myſelf, when I waked, in a place a great deal too hot for my conſtitution.—What a terrible thing it is to be kept in ſuch a quaking
ſtate!—I heard a noiſe—I hear it again—Oh, I am a loſt man! (He falls down hiding his face.)
div.stage: DASHINGTON and JAQUELINA enter through the private avenue.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Well, we have got out of the Robbers' clutches.—Still I wiſh we had eſcaped into a more agreeable place.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Since we are ſafe from thoſe wretches, I feel perfect ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: But the little account I have to anſwer, I am not at all convinced will be ſettled to my ſatiſfaction.—Who have we here?—Some poor devil!

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I am no devil, and I wiſh to have nothing to do with devils—Oh!—Oh!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Look up.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: I dare not look at any thing ſo frightful.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Look up, my good fellow.

sp.speaker: Juan.
sp.p: Don't think to wheedle me, Beelzebub—I defy the devil and all his works.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Now I ſhall ſee if this fellow can't give a better account.—Hey! what's here?—Why, this is ſorcery with a witneſs.—A woman too!—What, Signor Conjuror, you found you did not like ſolitary confinement, and flew away to fetch yourſelf a companion?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: If you will allow me, my Lord, to remove from this place, or at leaſt conduct this lady to a pleaſanter apartment, you may very eaſily be ſatisfied as to what now raiſes your wonder.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, as you clearly have the knack of flying through ſtone walls, I conclude you will
be juſt as ſafe in one place as another.—So come with me, and let me know the particulars of this extraordinary tranſaction; and you blockhead, (To Juan.) you may come too. Pray, Sir, (To Daſhington.) walk before me, that if you do take it into your head to vaniſh again, I may at leaſt have the pleaſure of ſeeing whether you fly or ſink, or go off in a flaſh, or how. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: ANGELINA enters ſupported by Sir STURDY O'TREMOR.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Oh yes, my dear Madam, I am certain I met the very man you inquire after. He looked ſcared, and yet furious—his eyes ſtarting out of his head; and he ran paſt me, as if he was flying for his life. I declare the ſight of him gave me a queer kind of feel—a ſort of a qualm all over. He ſeemed for all the world as if the rope had ſnapped with him at the gallows, and he was running away, half hanged.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh my failing ſtrength!—Could I follow him, I might ſtill convince him of my innocence.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: And is it that he doubts?—Oh, what a miſbeliever he muſt be!—Why, the man that can't read innocence in that ſweet face, knows nothing of Heaven's hand-writing.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Ah, my dear friend, have I found you at laſt?

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Oh, the ſight of you rejoices my heart. But I have loſt my dear girl.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
