sp.p: And I have found your dear girl.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: What do you tell me?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Nothing but truth: ſhe is ſafe, and I am ſafe, and all is right; but you brought me into a pretty ſcrape—I was very near getting a niche in the Book of Martyrs, by you.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Hey!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Nay, this is no time to dwell on paſt perils.—Jaquelina impatiently expects you; ſo make haſte to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: But this lady needs protection.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Mine is devoted to her. There is one of my ſervants; he will conduct you to your miſtreſs, while this lady may command from me whatever ſervice ſhe requires. So, without ceremony, fly as faſt as your worn-out frame will ſuffer you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir, do not let me tax your kindneſs, nor dull your joy with my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Madam, happineſs never found entrance in that breaſt which was not open to the ſorrows of a lovely woman.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You are truly generous; but indeed it grieves me much to treſpaſs thus. You are burdened with a being whoſe mind is rent with agony, and whoſe frame is enfeebled with fatigue and anguiſh.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Take comfort, Madam, and hope for happineſs; lean on my arm, and let me conduct you to ſafety and repoſe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am bound to you for ever. (She leans on him, and as they are going Alphonſo enters.)

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p:
Horror! 'tis he! Such a ſight would brace the arm of palſied cowardice, and in the breaſt of mercy's ſelf infuſe a tiger's fury. Matchleſs extent of woman's perfidy! a few hours paſt, with all the ſeeming of unſhaken conſtancy, wert
thou not kneeling at my feet, adjuring Heaven to witneſs for thy innocence? and now my eyes behold thee in the arms of thy curſed paramour! Villain! I thought my ſword had long ſince paid the debt I owed thee: I'll now make juſtice certain—and firſt to deal it here;—falſe woman, die! (Ruſhes at Angelina, who faints, and is ſupported by Daſhington, he defending her with his ſword. Sir Sturdy enters, and runs between them: he is followed by Leonora and Jaquelina.)

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: I thought this wild-looking gentleman would be falling foul of ſomebody. Sir, if you don't curb your paſſions, you may depend on it they will injure your health.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Heavens! my ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: My deareſt Leonora!

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: But whence this fury and diſtraction? How altered are your huſband's looks!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Altered, indeed, my ſiſter! ſome dreadful error has poſſeſſion of his mind.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Error! Oh, ſhameleſs woman! Can it be error now? there ſtands the author and proclaimer of your infamy.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Heaven can witneſs for me, that till this hour I ne'er beheld his face.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Give me leave, Sir, to ſay, that you are a moſt incomprehenſible gentleman. I am ready to admit, that on a certain ſtormy day, when you and I were weather-bound, I was more communicative than I ought to have been to a ſtranger; but may devils fly away with me in reality, if I ever mentioned to you that lady's name (which even yet I have not the honour of knowing); I only named to you the Lady Angelina d'Eſparza.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: And who but ſhe is owner of that name?

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p:
Why, that lady, is n't ſhe? (Pointing to
Leonora.) Pray, Ma'am, is n't your name Angelina d'Eſparza?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No; that is my ſiſter's name, the wife of Don Alphonſo.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Whew! here is a buſineſs! Am I really awake, or is this all a dream? Did I, or did I not, ſee you at Madrid?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: You did; while I was on a viſit to my ſiſter, during Don Alphonſo's abſence.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And—Lord, I begin to find that I have made a curſed deal of miſchief. The houſe, Madam, where you did me the honour to receive me, and allow me to expreſs my paſſion, was—

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: My ſiſter's; and to my ſhame I own, from apprehenſion that ſhe would diſapprove my conduct, it was without her knowledge I received you.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: (To Angelina.) My dear Ma'am, I beg you a million of pardons; and, my dear Sir, notwithſtanding you made a lunge clean through me, I confeſs you have great reaſon to be offended: but you ſee it was all a miſtake.

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: But whence could this miſtake ariſe? Leonora would never, ſurely, in her ſiſter's name, receive the viſits of a lover!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: No, Sir; ſhe admitted my viſits under no name at all, and obliged me too to promiſe not to make inquiries. Her commands I punctually obeyed; but at our laſt interview, as I was quitting the houſe, I heard a paſſer-by exclaim, "There lives the beauteous Angelina d'Eſparza!" I therefore naturally concluded that the beauteous Angelina was this lady. (To Leonora.)

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: What a blunder! and it is moſt extraordinary, that, though there is an Iriſhman among you, he has had no hand in it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Alphonſo!

sp.speaker: Alph.
sp.p: Oh, forgive me, deareſt Angelina!

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Although I confeſs myſelf horribly to blame, I muſt ſay, Ma'am, (To Angelina.) that huſband of yours is as haſty a gentleman as ever jerked a ſword out of its ſcabbard. The moment I mentioned the name, out came that damned long toledo, and in three ſeconds it was through me. Upon my ſoul the greateſt blame is due to your raſhneſs.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No, to your tattling.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Ah, that is a devil of a fault: never kiſs and tell.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: So I have found you out at laſt, and I am happy to tell you, that thoſe deſperate ruffians whom you (To Daſhington.) hindered from cutting our throats, are all in ſafe cuſtody. But what do you ſtay here ſo long for? There is a deviliſh good dinner ready; ſo come in, and be jolly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: We have diſcovered the error, Sir, which led us to ſuppoſe that this gentleman had encountered your ſon.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Why, I was ſure it muſt turn out a miſtake; for I have it under my ſon's own hand that he is at Lima, and intends to remain there; and I am not ſorry to find that he has taken himſelf a wife, ſince you wiſh to take another man for your huſband.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: And may I hope, Sir, that you will conſent to my marriage with your ward?

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: I conſent, with all my ſoul! She is to be married, not I; and, therefore, I don't ſee that my inclination has any thing to do but to follow hers.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Ah, my ſweet Jaquelina! if your father would think in this manner, it would be the ſaving of my life.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: And of mine too.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: Would it? Why, then, I have the ſatiſfaction of telling you that her father is now perfectly diſpoſed to let her pleaſe herſelf. He only placed her in a convent till he had informed himſelf thoroughly of your character and fortune; with both which he is now perfectly ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Then I am the happieſt man living.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: What, with ſuch a catalogue of maladies!

sp.speaker: Sir Stur.
sp.p: Love has cured them all, and I feel at this moment that I am as ſtout a man as ever.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: If you are not—Hercules muſt have been a ſhrimp to you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Now, my dear Guardy, I have but one favour to aſk, which is, that you will relinquiſh your office, and ceaſe to be an Inquiſitor.

sp.speaker: Mig.
sp.p: To that I can't conſent; for I am not ſure that any other perſon holding my office would do ſo little miſchief as myſelf.

sp.speaker: Daſh.
sp.p: Yours is the ſyſtem of true philanthropy—Not to be contented with ſimply doing good, but alſo to labour to prevent the evil deſigns of others—not only to practiſe virtue, but to preſerve the helpleſs from virtue's foes.

lg.l: From ſorrow and perils tormenting,
Since now we are happily free,
Our pleaſure in harmony venting,
Let's pour forth the numbers of glee.
So merrily, merrily ſinging;
Let joy's ſprightly ſound
Be wafted around,
While the bells are ſo merrily ringing.
What tranſport! misfortunes ideal,
And ſpringing from error to find!
And thoſe tranſports will all become real,
If you to our errors prove kind.
